questions.question_text: Which two actions must be taken when assessing an existing wireless network implementation for its readiness to support voice traffic? (Choose two.)

choices.D: Check for uniform radio coverage across the floors.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A. Check for high channel utilization.
C. Check for latency over wireless.

Selected Answer: AC
AC. voice traffic cares about jitters and latency. high channel utilization connects to jitters. latency over wireless is obvious. Not B because roaming affects only when devices move between access points.

Selected Answer: BC
For reliable voice support over wireless, we need low-latency and seamless roaming.

Selected Answer: AB
A&B. C is a bit tricky because latency matters but the keyword is "latency" not "high latency". There is always latency but high latency is a problem.

Voice enemies: Delay and Latency. High utilization is bad for all kind of traffic, not only voice, since voice should be prioritized, it shouldn't matter. Coverage is just simply NO service... all apps need service, no specific problem for voice. Power changes... wireless issues, generic wireless TBS.

Selected Answer: CD
For voice:
good radio coverage, 20% cell overlap.
Low latency, jitter, packet loss.

in my opinion there are three options correct: A (channel utilization), B (roaming delay can cause line drop), D (actually the requirement is minimum poert -67dBm but uniform coverage could mean the same requirement..). Which one of three do we ignore? Peraphs roaming delay is measurable only in post deployment and not in an initial assessment?

Selected Answer: AB
Poor call quality 
– Red/Yellow QoS – TSM Report
– High Channel Utilization
– High Roaming delay
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/wireless/technology/vowlan/troubleshooting/vowlan_troubleshoot.pdf

Selected Answer: AC
ABC all correct

Selected Answer: AB
AB seems logical

Selected Answer: AB
A) It can cause jitter
B) It can cause line drop
C) Should not be high latency within same network. Little latency still can talk but slower.
D) No reason to get voice coverage if no wifi data coverage. That's another requirement for greater coverage.
E) Seldom to care it.
A, B - IS SCORRECT

Selected Answer: AC
High channel utilization can lead to packet loss and delay, which can impact the quality of voice calls.

A & B
https://community.cisco.com/t5/wireless/channel-utilization/td-p/2716667

choices.B: Redistribute using metric type 1 into OSPF
choices.C: Redistribute using metric type 2 into EIGRP
choices.A: Redistribute using metric type 2 into OSPF
choices.D: Redistribute using metric type 1 into EIGRP

questions.question_text: Company XYZ has two routing domains in their network EIGRP and OSPF. The company wants to provide full reachability between the two domains by implementing redistribution on a router running both protocols. They need to design the redistribution in a way that the OSPF routers will see link costs added to external routes. How must the redistribution strategy be designed for this network?

discussion.content:
B.
https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=27573&seqNum=4#:~:text=Routes%20are%20redistributed%20in%20OSPF,shown%20in%20Figure%2014%2D2.
B laa brader

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B

Selected Answer: B
OSPF type 1 adds cost of each link - type 2 does not
https://community.cisco.com/t5/routers-small-business/metric-type-in-ospf/td-p/2624188#:~:text=A%20type%202%20route%20has,to%20reach%20the%20external%20networks.

Selected Answer: B
an esy B

Selected Answer: B
What's wrong for the guy wrote C or D for this answer????
B for sure.

Selected Answer: A
In this scenario, the company wants the OSPF routers to see link costs added to external routes. This means that when redistributing routes from EIGRP into OSPF, the redistributed routes should use a metric that reflects the link cost.
The best way to achieve this is to use metric type 2 when redistributing into OSPF.

Selected Answer: B
B for sure

Selected Answer: B
B for sure.
easy B
should be A

questions.question_text: The administrator of a small branch office wants to implement the Layer 2 network without running STP. The office has some redundant paths. Which mechanism can the administrator use to allow redundancy without creating Layer 2 loops?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
In theory all answers can accomplish redundancy while eliminating the necessity of STP.
This is a small branch office thus B,C do not apply. Answer D can be applied but it is overlapped by answer A which would be the optimal one for a branch without STP.

Selected Answer: A
Flex links are a pair of a Layer 2 interfaces (switch ports or port channels) where one interface is configured to act as a backup to the other

Selected Answer: A
It allows for the automatic failover of traffic from a primary link to a backup link in the event of a link failure, without the need for the Spanning Tree Protocol (STP).

Selected Answer: A
A, correct as per https://community.cisco.com/t5/networking-blogs/flexlink-in-cisco-layer-2-network/ba-p/3106779

Selected Answer: D
I vote for D

comments.content: Link bundling could cause Layer 2 Loop
fyi, the switch will disable STP on flex links

choices.A: Use two port channels as Flex links
choices.B: Use double-sided VPC on both switches

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The technology that provides a simplified and controlled approach to interconnecting multicast domains across multiple autonomous systems is MSDP (Multicast Source Discovery Protocol). MSDP is specifically designed for inter-domain multicast routing and allows autonomous systems to share information about active multicast sources.

MSDP enables the exchange of multicast source information between the border routers of different domains. It allows receivers in one domain to learn about multicast sources in another domain, enabling multicast traffic to be distributed across multiple domains in a controlled and coordinated manner.

Selected Answer: B
B correct , MSDP provides inter-domain access to multicast sources in all domains by enabling all Rendezvous Points (RPs) to discover multicast sources outside of their domains.

questions.question_text: Company XYZ has a multicast domain that spans across multiple autonomous systems. The company wants to choose a technology that provides a simplified and controlled approach to interconnecting the multicast domains. Which technology is the best fit for this purpose?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I choose D also. Trading app should be higher priority than VoIP, as ibank develops low latency technology for immediate trading, but voice order still needs a human processing that much slower, then able to talk is enough.

Selected Answer: D
Most Cisco devices now have multi-level priority queues
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst9400/software/release/16-6/configuration_guide/qos/b_166_qos_9400_cg/b_166_qos_9400_cg_chapter_01.html
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/12_2sb/feature/guide/mpq.html

Selected Answer: D
D. Each port supports eight egress queues, of which two can be given a priority. https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst9400/software/release/16-6/configuration_guide/qos/b_166_qos_9400_cg/b_166_qos_9400_cg_chapter_01.html#concept_zs4_1db_p1b

Selected Answer: D
D. Each port supports eight egress queues, of which two can be given a priority. https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst9400/software/release/16-6/configuration_guide/qos/b_166_qos_9400_cg/b_166_qos_9400_cg_chapter_01.html#concept_zs4_1db_p1b

Selected Answer: D
Assigning separate priority queues for the custom application and VoIP ensures that they are given the highest priority and can be transmitted with minimal delay, regardless of the traffic congestion on the network.

There are only 2 answers (B, D) that can meet two requirements: TCP based stock trading app & VoIP. 
Since it does not give any reference to hardware, MLP is still a good choice - https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/qos_conmgt/configuration/xe-3s/asr903/qos-conmgt-xe-3s-asr903-book/m_qos-conmgt-multilevel-pq.pdf

What a question, A is wrong - It clear say this tcp app needs to be prioritized over all traffic ... . B is also wrong because app needs to be prioritize over all other traffic which includes VoIP does it?... .
C is wrong because it doesn't matter whether it is UDP or TCP in the other queue.
D ?? only remaining one and with MPQ possible.
it is a TCP-app and nothing is mentioned regarding time sensitivity. also most hardware has only 1P queue. I will stick to A as the TCP App will compete with Voip in answer D

comments.content: For multiple priority queues, you can use the priority level command to configure a level of priority service on a class in a policy map.

I think B, VOIP should input priority queue rather than CBWFQ.
not D due to separate priority queue, I think only have one priority and CBWFQ queue within a interface.

discussion.content:
D
Without two individual dedicated queues, both VoIP & Custom app might face degradation of service

questions.question_text: A financial company requires that a custom TCP-based stock-trading application be prioritized over all other traffic for the business due to the associated revenue. The company also requires that VoIP be prioritized for manual trades. Which directive should be followed when a QoS strategy is developed for the business?

choices.A: Interleave the custom application with other TCP applications in the same CBWFQ queue
choices.D: The custom application and VoIP must be assigned their own separate priority queue
choices.C: Avoid placing the custom application in a CBWFQ queue that contains other UDP applications
choices.B: Allow VoIP and the custom application to share the same priority queue
